Title: Keep your drivers up to date
Content: GPU, chipset, and peripheral drivers improve performance, fix bugs, and optimize new games.

Title: Take care of your PC temperature
Content: Overheating reduces performance. Make sure you have good airflow, clean dust, and monitor temperatures.

Title: Use a high-performance power plan
Content: In Windows, select the High performance or Ultimate performance plan to avoid CPU and GPU limitations while gaming.

Title: Adjust graphics according to your hardware
Content: Not everything has to be set to “Ultra.” Adjusting shadows, antialiasing, or render distance can give you many extra FPS without noticeable visual quality loss.

Title: Close background programs
Content: Browsers, launchers, and unnecessary apps consume RAM and CPU. Fewer processes mean more resources for the game.

Title: Install games on an SSD
Content: Loading times are drastically reduced and the system feels much smoother. NVMe is even better.

Title: Perform regular maintenance
Content: Clean fans, replace thermal paste periodically, and check cables. A clean PC performs better and lasts longer.

Title: Keep the operating system optimized
Content: Avoid unnecessary startup software, disable animations if your PC is modest, and keep the system up to date.

Title: Use your monitor’s native resolution
Content: Playing outside the native resolution can cause blurry images or lower performance. Adjust resolution and scaling properly.

Title: Enable technologies like FreeSync or G-Sync
Content: These eliminate screen tearing and make gameplay feel much smoother, especially when your FPS fluctuates.

Title: Invest in good audio or gaming headphones
Content: Good sound improves immersion and gives you a competitive edge by detecting footsteps, shots, and directions.

Title: Learn how to monitor your performance
Content: FPS, CPU/GPU usage, and temperatures help you detect bottlenecks and issues before they get worse.

Title: Be careful with overclocking
Content: It can improve performance, but if done incorrectly it reduces hardware lifespan. Only do it if you know what you’re doing.

Title: Prioritize a wired (Ethernet) connection
Content: Wi-Fi can be unstable. For online gaming, a LAN cable reduces latency and packet loss.

Title: Adjust in-game sensitivity
Content: Not everything depends on the mouse or controller. Configure in-game sensitivity for better precision and consistency.

Title: Keep free space on your drives
Content: A full SSD loses performance. Try to keep at least 20% free space.

Title: Download games and mods only from trusted sources
Content: Avoid malware that can steal accounts, affect performance, or damage your system.

Title: Take care of your ergonomics
Content: Good posture, proper monitor height, and frequent breaks prevent fatigue and long-term injuries.

Title: Playing better also means knowing when to rest
Content: Long sessions without breaks lower your real performance. Resting is also part of competitive gaming.
